groups.brief: This document defines semantic conventions for the OpenTracing Shim
groups.note: These conventions are used by the OpenTracing Shim layer.

attributes.name: opentracing.ref_type

members.brief: The parent Span depends on the child Span in some capacity
The parent Span doesn't depend in any way on the result of the child Span

attributes.brief: Parent-child Reference type
attributes.note: The causal relationship between a child Span and a parent Span.

groups.brief: Describes GenAI operation span.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.max_tokens
attributes.brief: The maximum number of tokens the model generates for a request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.temperature
attributes.brief: The temperature setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.top_p
attributes.brief: The top_p sampling setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.top_k
attributes.brief: The top_k sampling setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.stop_sequences
attributes.brief: List of sequences that the model will use to stop generating further tokens.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.frequency_penalty
attributes.brief: The frequency penalty setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.presence_penalty
attributes.brief: The presence penalty setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.id
attributes.brief: The unique identifier for the completion.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.finish_reasons
attributes.brief: Array of reasons the model stopped generating tokens, corresponding to each generation received.

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.input_tokens
attributes.brief: The number of tokens used in the GenAI input (prompt).

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.output_tokens
attributes.brief: The number of tokens used in the GenAI response (completion).

attributes.name: gen_ai.system
attributes.brief: The Generative AI product as identified by the client or server instrumentation.
attributes.note:
The actual GenAI product may differ from the one identified by the client. For example, when using OpenAI client libraries to communicate with Mistral, the `gen_ai.system` is set to `openai` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.
For custom model, a custom friendly name SHOULD be used. If none of these options apply, the `gen_ai.system` SHOULD be set to `_OTHER`.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.model
attributes.brief: The name of the GenAI model a request is being made to.
attributes.note: The name of the GenAI model a request is being made to. If the model is supplied by a vendor, then the value must be the exact name of the model requested. If the model is a fine-tuned custom model, the value should have a more specific name than the base model that's been fine-tuned.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.model
attributes.brief: The name of the model that generated the response.
attributes.note: If available. The name of the GenAI model that provided the response. If the model is supplied by a vendor, then the value must be the exact name of the model actually used. If the model is a fine-tuned custom model, the value should have a more specific name than the base model that's been fine-tuned.

groups.brief: In the lifetime of an GenAI span, events for prompts sent and completions received may be created, depending on the configuration of the instrumentation.

attributes.name: gen_ai.prompt
attributes.brief: The full prompt sent to the GenAI model.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if corresponding event is enabled

attributes.note: It's RECOMMENDED to format prompts as JSON string matching [OpenAI messages format](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-generation)

groups.name: gen_ai.content.prompt

groups.brief: In the lifetime of an GenAI span, events for prompts sent and completions received may be created, depending on the configuration of the instrumentation.

attributes.name: gen_ai.completion
attributes.brief: The full response received from the GenAI model.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if corresponding event is enabled

attributes.note: It's RECOMMENDED to format completions as JSON string matching [OpenAI messages format](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-generation)

groups.name: gen_ai.content.completion

groups.brief: Measures the time taken to perform a DNS lookup.

attributes.name: dns.question.name
attributes.brief: The name being queried.
attributes.note: If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes the error the DNS lookup failed with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if an error has occurred.

attributes.note: Instrumentations SHOULD use error code such as one of errors reported by `getaddrinfo`([Linux or other POSIX systems](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/getaddrinfo.3.html) / [Windows](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/win32/api/ws2tcpip/nf-ws2tcpip-getaddrinfo)) or one reported by the runtime or client library. If error code is not available, the full name of exception type SHOULD be used.

groups.brief: A service instance.

attributes.name: service.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the service API or implementation. The format is not defined by these conventions.

attributes.name: service.name
attributes.brief: Logical name of the service.
attributes.note: MUST be the same for all instances of horizontally scaled services. If the value was not specified, SDKs MUST fallback to `unknown_service:` concatenated with [`process.executable.name`](process.md), e.g. `unknown_service:bash`. If `process.executable.name` is not available, the value MUST be set to `unknown_service`.

groups.brief: A serverless instance.

attributes.name: cloud.resource_id
attributes.brief: Cloud provider-specific native identifier of the monitored cloud resource (e.g. an [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html) on AWS, a [fully qualified resource ID](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) on Azure, a [full resource name](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/resource_names#full_resource_name) on GCP)
attributes.note:
On some cloud providers, it may not be possible to determine the full ID at startup,
so it may be necessary to set `cloud.resource_id` as a span attribute instead.

The exact value to use for `cloud.resource_id` depends on the cloud provider.
The following well-known definitions MUST be used if you set this attribute and they apply:

* **AWS Lambda:** The function [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html).
  Take care not to use the "invoked ARN" directly but replace any
  [alias suffix](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-aliases.html)
  with the resolved function version, as the same runtime instance may be invocable with
  multiple different aliases.
* **GCP:** The [URI of the resource](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/full-resource-names)
* **Azure:** The [Fully Qualified Resource ID](https://docs.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) of the invoked function,
  *not* the function app, having the form
  `/subscriptions/<SUBSCIPTION_GUID>/resourceGroups/<RG>/providers/Microsoft.Web/sites/<FUNCAPP>/functions/<FUNC>`.
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider.

attributes.name: faas.version
attributes.brief: The immutable version of the function being executed.
attributes.note:
Depending on the cloud provider and platform, use:

* **AWS Lambda:** The [function version](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-versions.html)
  (an integer represented as a decimal string).
* **Google Cloud Run (Services):** The [revision](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/managing/revisions)
  (i.e., the function name plus the revision suffix).
* **Google Cloud Functions:** The value of the
  [`K_REVISION` environment variable](https://cloud.google.com/functions/docs/env-var#runtime_environment_variables_set_automatically).
* **Azure Functions:** Not applicable. Do not set this attribute.

attributes.name: faas.instance
attributes.brief: The execution environment ID as a string, that will be potentially reused for other invocations to the same function/function version.
attributes.note: * **AWS Lambda:** Use the (full) log stream name.

attributes.name: faas.max_memory
attributes.brief: The amount of memory available to the serverless function converted to Bytes.
attributes.note: It's recommended to set this attribute since e.g. too little memory can easily stop a Java AWS Lambda function from working correctly. On AWS Lambda, the environment variable `AWS_LAMBDA_FUNCTION_MEMORY_SIZE` provides this information (which must be multiplied by 1,048,576).

attributes.name: faas.name
attributes.brief: The name of the single function that this runtime instance executes.
attributes.note:
This is the name of the function as configured/deployed on the FaaS
platform and is usually different from the name of the callback
function (which may be stored in the
[`code.namespace`/`code.function`](/docs/general/attributes.md#source-code-attributes)
span attributes).

For some cloud providers, the above definition is ambiguous. The following
definition of function name MUST be used for this attribute
(and consequently the span name) for the listed cloud providers/products:

* **Azure:**  The full name `<FUNCAPP>/<FUNC>`, i.e., function app name
  followed by a forward slash followed by the function name (this form
  can also be seen in the resource JSON for the function).
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function
  app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider (see also the `cloud.resource_id` attribute).

groups.brief: A cloud environment (e.g. GCP, Azure, AWS)

attributes.name: cloud.provider
attributes.brief: Name of the cloud provider.

attributes.name: cloud.account.id
attributes.brief: The cloud account ID the resource is assigned to.

attributes.name: cloud.region
attributes.brief: The geographical region the resource is running.
attributes.note: Refer to your provider's docs to see the available regions, for example [Alibaba Cloud regions](https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/doc-detail/40654.htm), [AWS regions](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/regions_az/), [Azure regions](https://azure.microsoft.com/global-infrastructure/geographies/), [Google Cloud regions](https://cloud.google.com/about/locations), or [Tencent Cloud regions](https://www.tencentcloud.com/document/product/213/6091).

attributes.name: cloud.resource_id
attributes.brief: Cloud provider-specific native identifier of the monitored cloud resource (e.g. an [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html) on AWS, a [fully qualified resource ID](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) on Azure, a [full resource name](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/resource_names#full_resource_name) on GCP)
attributes.note:
On some cloud providers, it may not be possible to determine the full ID at startup,
so it may be necessary to set `cloud.resource_id` as a span attribute instead.

The exact value to use for `cloud.resource_id` depends on the cloud provider.
The following well-known definitions MUST be used if you set this attribute and they apply:

* **AWS Lambda:** The function [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html).
  Take care not to use the "invoked ARN" directly but replace any
  [alias suffix](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-aliases.html)
  with the resolved function version, as the same runtime instance may be invocable with
  multiple different aliases.
* **GCP:** The [URI of the resource](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/full-resource-names)
* **Azure:** The [Fully Qualified Resource ID](https://docs.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) of the invoked function,
  *not* the function app, having the form
  `/subscriptions/<SUBSCIPTION_GUID>/resourceGroups/<RG>/providers/Microsoft.Web/sites/<FUNCAPP>/functions/<FUNC>`.
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider.

attributes.name: cloud.availability_zone
attributes.brief: Cloud regions often have multiple, isolated locations known as zones to increase availability. Availability zone represents the zone where the resource is running.
attributes.note: Availability zones are called "zones" on Alibaba Cloud and Google Cloud.

attributes.name: cloud.platform

members.brief: Red Hat OpenShift on Alibaba Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on Google Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud

attributes.brief: The cloud platform in use.
attributes.note: The prefix of the service SHOULD match the one specified in `cloud.provider`.

groups.brief: Heroku dyno metadata

attributes.name: heroku.release.creation_timestamp
attributes.brief: Time and date the release was created

attributes.name: heroku.release.commit
attributes.brief: Commit hash for the current release

attributes.name: heroku.app.id
attributes.brief: Unique identifier for the application

groups.brief: Operations that access some remote service.

attributes.name: peer.service
attributes.brief: The [`service.name`](/docs/resource/README.md#service) of the remote service. SHOULD be equal to the actual `service.name` resource attribute of the remote service if any.

groups.brief: Describes device attributes.

attributes.name: device.id
attributes.brief: A unique identifier representing the device
attributes.note: The device identifier MUST only be defined using the values outlined below. This value is not an advertising identifier and MUST NOT be used as such. On iOS (Swift or Objective-C), this value MUST be equal to the [vendor identifier](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uidevice/1620059-identifierforvendor). On Android (Java or Kotlin), this value MUST be equal to the Firebase Installation ID or a globally unique UUID which is persisted across sessions in your application. More information can be found [here](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids) on best practices and exact implementation details. Caution should be taken when storing personal data or anything which can identify a user. GDPR and data protection laws may apply, ensure you do your own due diligence.

attributes.name: device.manufacturer
attributes.brief: The name of the device manufacturer
attributes.note: The Android OS provides this field via [Build](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build#MANUFACTURER). iOS apps SHOULD hardcode the value `Apple`.

attributes.name: device.model.identifier
attributes.brief: The model identifier for the device
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a machine-readable version of the model identifier rather than the market or consumer-friendly name of the device.

attributes.name: device.model.name
attributes.brief: The marketing name for the device model
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a human-readable version of the device model rather than a machine-readable alternative.

groups.brief: The iOS platform on which the iOS application is running.

attributes.name: ios.state

members.brief: The app has become `active`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidBecomeActive`.
The app is now `inactive`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillResignActive`.
The app is now in the background. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidEnterBackground`.
The app is now in the foreground. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillEnterForeground`.
The app is about to terminate. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillTerminate`.

attributes.brief: Deprecated use the `device.app.lifecycle` event definition including `ios.state` as a payload field instead.
attributes.note: The iOS lifecycle states are defined in the [UIApplicationDelegate documentation](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiapplicationdelegate#1656902), and from which the `OS terminology` column values are derived.
attributes.deprecated: Moved to a payload field of `device.app.lifecycle`.

groups.brief: Deprecated rpc message attributes.

attributes.name: message.type
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `rpc.message.type` instead.

attributes.name: message.id
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `rpc.message.id` instead.

attributes.name: message.compressed_size
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `rpc.message.compressed_size` instead.

attributes.name: message.uncompressed_size
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `rpc.message.uncompressed_size` instead.

groups.brief: A host is defined as a computing instance. For example, physical servers, virtual machines, switches or disk array.

attributes.name: host.id
attributes.brief: Unique host ID. For Cloud, this must be the instance_id assigned by the cloud provider. For non-containerized systems, this should be the `machine-id`. See the table below for the sources to use to determine the `machine-id` based on operating system.

attributes.name: host.name
attributes.brief: Name of the host. On Unix systems, it may contain what the hostname command returns, or the fully qualified hostname, or another name specified by the user.

attributes.name: host.type
attributes.brief: Type of host. For Cloud, this must be the machine type.

attributes.name: host.arch
attributes.brief: The CPU architecture the host system is running on.

attributes.name: host.image.name
attributes.brief: Name of the VM image or OS install the host was instantiated from.

attributes.name: host.image.id
attributes.brief: VM image ID or host OS image ID. For Cloud, this value is from the provider.

attributes.name: host.image.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the VM image or host OS as defined in [Version Attributes](/docs/resource/README.md#version-attributes).

attributes.name: host.ip
attributes.brief: Available IP addresses of the host, excluding loopback interfaces.
attributes.note: IPv4 Addresses MUST be specified in dotted-quad notation. IPv6 addresses MUST be specified in the [RFC 5952](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5952.html) format.

attributes.name: host.mac
attributes.brief: Available MAC addresses of the host, excluding loopback interfaces.
attributes.note: MAC Addresses MUST be represented in [IEEE RA hexadecimal form](https://standards.ieee.org/wp-content/uploads/import/documents/tutorials/eui.pdf): as hyphen-separated octets in uppercase hexadecimal form from most to least significant.

attributes.name: host.cpu.vendor.id
attributes.brief: Processor manufacturer identifier. A maximum 12-character string.
attributes.note: [CPUID](https://wiki.osdev.org/CPUID) command returns the vendor ID string in EBX, EDX and ECX registers. Writing these to memory in this order results in a 12-character string.

attributes.name: host.cpu.family
attributes.brief: Family or generation of the CPU.

attributes.name: host.cpu.model.id
attributes.brief: Model identifier. It provides more granular information about the CPU, distinguishing it from other CPUs within the same family.

attributes.name: host.cpu.model.name
attributes.brief: Model designation of the processor.

attributes.name: host.cpu.stepping
attributes.brief: Stepping or core revisions.

attributes.name: host.cpu.cache.l2.size
attributes.brief: The amount of level 2 memory cache available to the processor (in Bytes).

groups.brief: Semantic convention for attributes that describe the publish messaging destination on broker. The term Publish Destination refers to the destination the message was originally published to. These attributes should be used on the consumer side when information about the publish destination is available and different than the destination message are consumed from.
groups.note:
Publish destination attributes should be set on publish, receive,
or other spans describing messaging operations.
Destination attributes should be set when the messaging operation handles
single messages. When the operation handles a batch of messages,
the destination attributes should only be applied when the attribute value
applies to all messages in the batch.
In other cases, destination attributes may be set on links.

attributes.name: messaging.destination_publish.anonymous
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the publish message destination is anonymous (could be unnamed or have auto-generated name).

attributes.name: messaging.destination_publish.name
attributes.brief: The name of the original destination the message was published to
attributes.note:
The name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic, or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the original destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

groups.brief: Defines minimal set of attributes used by all messaging systems.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If span describes operation on a single message or if the value applies to all messages in the batch.

attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.message.id
attributes.brief: A value used by the messaging system as an identifier for the message, represented as a string.

requirement_level.recommended: If span describes operation on a single message.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.type

members.brief: One or more messages are provided for publishing to an intermediary. If a single message is published, the context of the "Publish" span can be used as the creation context and no "Create" span needs to be created.
A message is created. "Create" spans always refer to a single message and are used to provide a unique creation context for messages in batch publishing scenarios.
One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

attributes.brief: A string identifying the type of the messaging operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

groups.brief: Defines a full set of attributes used in messaging systems.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: messaging.client.id
attributes.brief: A unique identifier for the client that consumes or produces a message.

attributes.name: messaging.message.conversation_id
attributes.brief: The conversation ID identifying the conversation to which the message belongs, represented as a string. Sometimes called "Correlation ID".

attributes.name: messaging.message.envelope.size
attributes.brief: The size of the message body and metadata in bytes.
attributes.note:
This can refer to both the compressed or uncompressed size. If both sizes are known, the uncompressed
size should be used.

attributes.name: messaging.message.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the message body in bytes.
attributes.note:
This can refer to both the compressed or uncompressed body size. If both sizes are known, the uncompressed
body size should be used.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If span describes operation on a single message or if the value applies to all messages in the batch.

attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.message.id
attributes.brief: A value used by the messaging system as an identifier for the message, represented as a string.

requirement_level.recommended: If span describes operation on a single message.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.type

members.brief: One or more messages are provided for publishing to an intermediary. If a single message is published, the context of the "Publish" span can be used as the creation context and no "Create" span needs to be created.
A message is created. "Create" spans always refer to a single message and are used to provide a unique creation context for messages in batch publishing scenarios.
One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

attributes.brief: A string identifying the type of the messaging operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: messaging.batch.message_count
attributes.brief: The number of messages sent, received, or processed in the scope of the batching operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If the span describes an operation on a batch of messages.

attributes.note: Instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `messaging.batch.message_count` on spans that operate with a single message. When a messaging client library supports both batch and single-message API for the same operation, instrumentations SHOULD use `messaging.batch.message_count` for batching APIs and SHOULD NOT use it for single-message APIs.

attributes.name: messaging.consumer.group.name
attributes.brief: The name of the consumer group with which a consumer is associated.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.consumer.group.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.anonymous
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the message destination is anonymous (could be unnamed or have auto-generated name).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If value is `true`. When missing, the value is assumed to be `false`.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.partition.id
attributes.brief: The identifier of the partition messages are sent to or received from, unique within the `messaging.destination.name`.

requirement_level.recommended: When applicable.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.subscription.name
attributes.brief: The name of the destination subscription from which a message is consumed.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.destination.subscription.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.template
attributes.brief: Low cardinality representation of the messaging destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available. Instrumentations MUST NOT use `messaging.destination.name` as template unless low-cardinality of destination name is guaranteed.

attributes.note: Destination names could be constructed from templates. An example would be a destination name involving a user name or product id. Although the destination name in this case is of high cardinality, the underlying template is of low cardinality and can be effectively used for grouping and aggregation.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.temporary
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the message destination is temporary and might not exist anymore after messages are processed.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If value is `true`. When missing, the value is assumed to be `false`.

attributes.name: messaging.system
attributes.brief: The messaging system as identified by the client instrumentation.
attributes.note: The actual messaging system may differ from the one known by the client. For example, when using Kafka client libraries to communicate with Azure Event Hubs, the `messaging.system` is set to `kafka` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the messaging intermediary node where the operation was performed.

requirement_level.recommended: If applicable for this messaging system.

attributes.note:
Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `network.peer.*` attributes are applicable.
Network peer address and port are important when the application interacts with individual intermediary nodes directly,
If a messaging operation involved multiple network calls (for example retries), the address of the last contacted node SHOULD be used.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port of the messaging intermediary node where the operation was performed.

requirement_level.recommended: if and only if `network.peer.address` is set.

groups.brief: Attributes that describe messaging operation along with network information.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

attributes.note:

One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

attributes.note: If the key type is not string, it's string representation has to be supplied for the attribute. If the key has no unambiguous, canonical string form, don't include its value.

attributes.name: messaging.gcp_pubsub.message.ordering_key

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.
attributes.note:
The `messaging.operation.name` has the following list of well-known values in the context of Google Pub/Sub.
If one of them applies, then the respective value MUST be used; otherwise, a custom value MAY be used.

- `ack` and `nack` for settlement operations
- `send` for publishing operations
- `modack` for extending the lease for a single message or batch of messages
- `subscribe` for operations that represent the time from after the message was received to when the message is acknowledged, negatively acknowledged, or expired.
- `create` and `receive` for [common messaging operations](/docs/messaging/messaging-spans.md#common-messaging-operations)

attributes.brief: Azure Service Bus operation name.
attributes.note:
The operation name SHOULD match one of the following values:

- sender operations: `send`, `schedule`, `cancel_scheduled`
- transaction operations: `create_transaction`, `commit_transaction`, `rollback_transaction`
- receiver operation: `receive`, `peek`, `receive_deferred`, `renew_message_lock`
- settlement operations: `abandon`, `complete`, `defer`, `dead_letter`, `delete`
- session operations: `accept_session`, `get_session_state`, `set_session_state`, `renew_session_lock`

If none of the above operation names apply, the attribute SHOULD be set
to the name of the client method in snake_case.

attributes.name: messaging.servicebus.disposition_status

members.brief: Message is sent to dead letter queue

attributes.brief: Describes the [settlement type](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/service-bus-messaging/message-transfers-locks-settlement#peeklock).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if `messaging.operation` is `settle`.

attributes.name: messaging.servicebus.message.delivery_count
attributes.brief: Number of deliveries that have been attempted for this message.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If delivery count is available and is bigger than 0.

groups.brief: Attributes for Azure Event Hubs

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: messaging.eventhubs.message.enqueued_time
attributes.brief: The UTC epoch seconds at which the message has been accepted and stored in the entity.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If span describes operation on a single message or if the value applies to all messages in the batch.

attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.message.id
attributes.brief: A value used by the messaging system as an identifier for the message, represented as a string.

requirement_level.recommended: If span describes operation on a single message.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.type

members.brief: One or more messages are provided for publishing to an intermediary. If a single message is published, the context of the "Publish" span can be used as the creation context and no "Create" span needs to be created.
A message is created. "Create" spans always refer to a single message and are used to provide a unique creation context for messages in batch publishing scenarios.
One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

attributes.brief: A string identifying the type of the messaging operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: messaging.batch.message_count
attributes.brief: The number of messages sent, received, or processed in the scope of the batching operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If the span describes an operation on a batch of messages.

attributes.note: Instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `messaging.batch.message_count` on spans that operate with a single message. When a messaging client library supports both batch and single-message API for the same operation, instrumentations SHOULD use `messaging.batch.message_count` for batching APIs and SHOULD NOT use it for single-message APIs.

attributes.name: messaging.consumer.group.name
attributes.brief: Azure Event Hubs [consumer group name](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/event-hubs/event-hubs-features#consumer-groups).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: On consumer spans.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.partition.id
attributes.brief: String representation of the partition id messages are sent to or received from, unique within the Event Hub.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: Azure Event Hubs operation name.
attributes.note:
The operation name SHOULD match one of the following values:

- `send`
- `receive`
- `process`
- `checkpoint`
- `get_partition_properties`
- `get_event_hub_properties`

If none of the above operation names apply, the attribute SHOULD be set
to the name of the client method in snake_case.

groups.brief: Describes deprecated otel.library attributes.
This document defines attributes that represents an occurrence of a lifecycle transition on the Android platform.

attributes.name: android.state

members.brief: Any time before Activity.onResume() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.startService() has been called in the app for the first time.
Any time after Activity.onPause() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.stopService() has been called when the app was in the foreground state.
Any time after Activity.onResume() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.startService() has been called when the app was in either the created or background states.

attributes.brief: Deprecated use the `device.app.lifecycle` event definition including `android.state` as a payload field instead.
attributes.note: The Android lifecycle states are defined in [Activity lifecycle callbacks](https://developer.android.com/guide/components/activities/activity-lifecycle#lc), and from which the `OS identifiers` are derived.

attributes.name: db.statement
attributes.brief: The database statement being executed.

attributes.name: db.cassandra.table
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `db.collection.name` instead.

attributes.name: db.cosmosdb.container
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `db.collection.name` instead.

attributes.name: db.mongodb.collection

attributes.name: db.sql.table
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `db.collection.name` instead.

attributes.deprecated: Deprecated, no replacement at this time.

attributes.brief: Deprecated, no general replacement at this time. For Elasticsearch, use `db.elasticsearch.node.name` instead.
attributes.deprecated: Deprecated, no general replacement at this time. For Elasticsearch, use `db.elasticsearch.node.name` instead.

attributes.name: db.elasticsearch.cluster.name
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `db.namespace` instead.

attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `db.client.connection.pool.name` instead.

groups.brief: Attributes used by non-OTLP exporters to represent OpenTelemetry Scope's concepts.

attributes.name: otel.scope.name
attributes.brief: The name of the instrumentation scope - (`InstrumentationScope.Name` in OTLP).

attributes.name: otel.scope.version
attributes.brief: The version of the instrumentation scope - (`InstrumentationScope.Version` in OTLP).

groups.brief: This semantic convention defines the attributes used to represent a feature flag evaluation as an event.

attributes.name: feature_flag.provider_name
attributes.brief: The name of the service provider that performs the flag evaluation.

attributes.name: feature_flag.variant
attributes.brief: SHOULD be a semantic identifier for a value. If one is unavailable, a stringified version of the value can be used.
attributes.note:
A semantic identifier, commonly referred to as a variant, provides a means
for referring to a value without including the value itself. This can
provide additional context for understanding the meaning behind a value.
For example, the variant `red` maybe be used for the value `#c05543`.

A stringified version of the value can be used in situations where a
semantic identifier is unavailable. String representation of the value
should be determined by the implementer.

attributes.name: feature_flag.key
attributes.brief: The unique identifier of the feature flag.

groups.name: feature_flag

groups.brief: This document defines semantic conventions to apply when instrumenting the GraphQL implementation. They map GraphQL operations to attributes on a Span.

attributes.name: graphql.operation.name
attributes.brief: The name of the operation being executed.

attributes.name: graphql.operation.type
attributes.brief: The type of the operation being executed.

attributes.name: graphql.document
attributes.brief: The GraphQL document being executed.
attributes.note: The value may be sanitized to exclude sensitive information.

groups.brief: Semantic Convention for HTTP Client

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If request has ended with an error.

attributes.note:
If the request fails with an error before response status code was sent or received,
`error.type` SHOULD be set to exception type (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable)
or a component-specific low cardinality error identifier.

If response status code was sent or received and status indicates an error according to [HTTP span status definition](/docs/http/http-spans.md),
`error.type` SHOULD be set to the status code number (represented as a string), an exception type (if thrown) or a component-specific error identifier.

The `error.type` value SHOULD be predictable and SHOULD have low cardinality.
Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low, but
telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time, when no
additional filters are applied.

If the request has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: http.request.header
attributes.brief: HTTP request headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all request headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
The `User-Agent` header is already captured in the `user_agent.original` attribute. Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.request.method

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.brief: HTTP request method.
attributes.note:
HTTP request method value SHOULD be "known" to the instrumentation.
By default, this convention defines "known" methods as the ones listed in [RFC9110](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-methods)
and the PATCH method defined in [RFC5789](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5789.html).

If the HTTP request method is not known to instrumentation, it MUST set the `http.request.method` attribute to `_OTHER`.

If the HTTP instrumentation could end up converting valid HTTP request methods to `_OTHER`, then it MUST provide a way to override
the list of known HTTP methods. If this override is done via environment variable, then the environment variable MUST be named
OTEL_INSTRUMENTATION_HTTP_KNOWN_METHODS and support a comma-separated list of case-sensitive known HTTP methods
(this list MUST be a full override of the default known method, it is not a list of known methods in addition to the defaults).

HTTP method names are case-sensitive and `http.request.method` attribute value MUST match a known HTTP method name exactly.
Instrumentations for specific web frameworks that consider HTTP methods to be case insensitive, SHOULD populate a canonical equivalent.
Tracing instrumentations that do so, MUST also set `http.request.method_original` to the original value.

attributes.name: http.request.method_original
attributes.brief: Original HTTP method sent by the client in the request line.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if it's different than `http.request.method`.

attributes.name: http.request.resend_count
attributes.brief: The ordinal number of request resending attempt (for any reason, including redirects).

requirement_level.recommended: if and only if request was retried.

attributes.note: The resend count SHOULD be updated each time an HTTP request gets resent by the client, regardless of what was the cause of the resending (e.g. redirection, authorization failure, 503 Server Unavailable, network issues, or any other).

attributes.name: http.response.header
attributes.brief: HTTP response headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all response headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

requirement_level.recommended: If `network.peer.address` is set.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If not `http` and `network.protocol.version` is set.

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note: Generally `tcp` for `HTTP/1.0`, `HTTP/1.1`, and `HTTP/2`. Generally `udp` for `HTTP/3`. Other obscure implementations are possible.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Host identifier of the ["URI origin"](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-uri-origin) HTTP request is sent to.
attributes.note: If an HTTP client request is explicitly made to an IP address, e.g. `http://x.x.x.x:8080`, then `server.address` SHOULD be the IP address `x.x.x.x`. A DNS lookup SHOULD NOT be used.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Port identifier of the ["URI origin"](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-uri-origin) HTTP request is sent to.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: url.full
attributes.brief: Absolute URL describing a network resource according to [RFC3986](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986)
attributes.note:
For network calls, URL usually has `scheme://host[:port][path][?query][#fragment]` format, where the fragment is not transmitted over HTTP, but if it is known, it SHOULD be included nevertheless.
`url.full` MUST NOT contain credentials passed via URL in form of `https://username:password@www.example.com/`. In such case username and password SHOULD be redacted and attribute's value SHOULD be `https://REDACTED:REDACTED@www.example.com/`.
`url.full` SHOULD capture the absolute URL when it is available (or can be reconstructed). Sensitive content provided in `url.full` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: user_agent.original
attributes.brief: Value of the [HTTP User-Agent](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.user-agent) header sent by the client.
examples: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 14_7_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/14.1.2 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1

groups.brief: Experimental attributes for HTTP Client spans

attributes.name: http.request.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the request payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.request.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the request in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the request line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and request body if any.

attributes.name: http.response.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the response payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.response.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the response in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the status line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and response body and trailers if any.

attributes.name: url.template
attributes.brief: The low-cardinality template of an [absolute path reference](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-4.2).
attributes.note: The `url.template` MUST have low cardinality. It is not usually available on HTTP clients, but may be known by the application or specialized HTTP instrumentation.

groups.brief: Semantic Convention for HTTP Server

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.note:

`error.type` SHOULD be set to exception type (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable)

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: http.request.method

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.note:

attributes.name: http.request.method_original
attributes.brief: Original HTTP method sent by the client in the request line.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if it's different than `http.request.method`.

attributes.name: http.response.header
attributes.brief: HTTP response headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all response headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

requirement_level.recommended: If `network.peer.address` is set.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If not `http` and `network.protocol.version` is set.

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note: Generally `tcp` for `HTTP/1.0`, `HTTP/1.1`, and `HTTP/2`. Generally `udp` for `HTTP/3`. Other obscure implementations are possible.

attributes.name: client.address
attributes.brief: Client address - domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.
attributes.note: The IP address of the original client behind all proxies, if known (e.g. from [Forwarded#for](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Forwarded#for), [X-Forwarded-For](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-For), or a similar header). Otherwise, the immediate client peer address.

attributes.name: client.port
attributes.brief: The port of whichever client was captured in `client.address`.
attributes.note: When observed from the server side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `client.port` SHOULD represent the client port behind any intermediaries,  for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: http.request.header
attributes.brief: HTTP request headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all request headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
The `User-Agent` header is already captured in the `user_agent.original` attribute. Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.route
attributes.brief: The matched route, that is, the path template in the format used by the respective server framework.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if it's available

attributes.note:
MUST NOT be populated when this is not supported by the HTTP server framework as the route attribute should have low-cardinality and the URI path can NOT substitute it.
SHOULD include the [application root](/docs/http/http-spans.md#http-server-definitions) if there is one.

attributes.name: network.local.address
attributes.brief: Local socket address. Useful in case of a multi-IP host.

attributes.name: network.local.port
attributes.brief: Local socket port. Useful in case of a multi-port host.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Name of the local HTTP server that received the request.
attributes.note: See [Setting `server.address` and `server.port` attributes](/docs/http/http-spans.md#setting-serveraddress-and-serverport-attributes).

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Port of the local HTTP server that received the request.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If `server.address` is set.

attributes.note: See [Setting `server.address` and `server.port` attributes](/docs/http/http-spans.md#setting-serveraddress-and-serverport-attributes).

attributes.name: url.path
attributes.brief: The [URI path](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.3) component
attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.path` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.query
attributes.brief: The [URI query](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.4) component

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.query` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.
attributes.note: The scheme of the original client request, if known (e.g. from [Forwarded#proto](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Forwarded#proto), [X-Forwarded-Proto](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-Proto), or a similar header). Otherwise, the scheme of the immediate peer request.

attributes.name: user_agent.original
attributes.brief: Value of the [HTTP User-Agent](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.user-agent) header sent by the client.
examples: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 14_7_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/14.1.2 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1

groups.brief: Experimental attributes for HTTP Server spans

attributes.name: http.request.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the request payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.request.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the request in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the request line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and request body if any.

attributes.name: http.response.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the response payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.response.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the response in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the status line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and response body and trailers if any.

groups.brief: Describes HTTP attributes.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If request has ended with an error.

attributes.note:
If the request fails with an error before response status code was sent or received,
`error.type` SHOULD be set to exception type (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable)
or a component-specific low cardinality error identifier.

If response status code was sent or received and status indicates an error according to [HTTP span status definition](/docs/http/http-spans.md),
`error.type` SHOULD be set to the status code number (represented as a string), an exception type (if thrown) or a component-specific error identifier.

The `error.type` value SHOULD be predictable and SHOULD have low cardinality.
Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low, but
telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time, when no
additional filters are applied.

If the request has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If not `http` and `network.protocol.version` is set.

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: http.request.method

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.brief: HTTP request method.
attributes.note:
HTTP request method value SHOULD be "known" to the instrumentation.
By default, this convention defines "known" methods as the ones listed in [RFC9110](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-methods)
and the PATCH method defined in [RFC5789](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5789.html).

If the HTTP request method is not known to instrumentation, it MUST set the `http.request.method` attribute to `_OTHER`.

If the HTTP instrumentation could end up converting valid HTTP request methods to `_OTHER`, then it MUST provide a way to override
the list of known HTTP methods. If this override is done via environment variable, then the environment variable MUST be named
OTEL_INSTRUMENTATION_HTTP_KNOWN_METHODS and support a comma-separated list of case-sensitive known HTTP methods
(this list MUST be a full override of the default known method, it is not a list of known methods in addition to the defaults).

HTTP method names are case-sensitive and `http.request.method` attribute value MUST match a known HTTP method name exactly.
Instrumentations for specific web frameworks that consider HTTP methods to be case insensitive, SHOULD populate a canonical equivalent.
Tracing instrumentations that do so, MUST also set `http.request.method_original` to the original value.

groups.brief: HTTP Client attributes

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If request has ended with an error.

attributes.note:
If the request fails with an error before response status code was sent or received,
`error.type` SHOULD be set to exception type (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable)
or a component-specific low cardinality error identifier.

If response status code was sent or received and status indicates an error according to [HTTP span status definition](/docs/http/http-spans.md),
`error.type` SHOULD be set to the status code number (represented as a string), an exception type (if thrown) or a component-specific error identifier.

The `error.type` value SHOULD be predictable and SHOULD have low cardinality.
Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low, but

If the request has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Host identifier of the ["URI origin"](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-uri-origin) HTTP request is sent to.
attributes.note: If an HTTP client request is explicitly made to an IP address, e.g. `http://x.x.x.x:8080`, then `server.address` SHOULD be the IP address `x.x.x.x`. A DNS lookup SHOULD NOT be used.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Port identifier of the ["URI origin"](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-uri-origin) HTTP request is sent to.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If not `http` and `network.protocol.version` is set.

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.brief: HTTP request method.
attributes.note:
HTTP request method value SHOULD be "known" to the instrumentation.
By default, this convention defines "known" methods as the ones listed in [RFC9110](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-methods)
and the PATCH method defined in [RFC5789](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5789.html).

groups.brief: Experimental HTTP attributes.

attributes.name: url.template
attributes.brief: The low-cardinality template of an [absolute path reference](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-4.2).
attributes.note: The `url.template` MUST have low cardinality. It is not usually available on HTTP clients, but may be known by the application or specialized HTTP instrumentation.

groups.brief: HTTP Server attributes

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If request has ended with an error.

attributes.note:
If the request fails with an error before response status code was sent or received,
`error.type` SHOULD be set to exception type (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable)
or a component-specific low cardinality error identifier.

If response status code was sent or received and status indicates an error according to [HTTP span status definition](/docs/http/http-spans.md),
`error.type` SHOULD be set to the status code number (represented as a string), an exception type (if thrown) or a component-specific error identifier.

The `error.type` value SHOULD be predictable and SHOULD have low cardinality.
Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low, but
