attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.
attributes.note: The scheme of the original client request, if known (e.g. from [Forwarded#proto](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Forwarded#proto), [X-Forwarded-Proto](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-Proto), or a similar header). Otherwise, the scheme of the immediate peer request.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if one was received/sent.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If not `http` and `network.protocol.version` is set.

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: http.route
attributes.brief: The matched route, that is, the path template in the format used by the respective server framework.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if it's available

attributes.note:
MUST NOT be populated when this is not supported by the HTTP server framework as the route attribute should have low-cardinality and the URI path can NOT substitute it.
SHOULD include the [application root](/docs/http/http-spans.md#http-server-definitions) if there is one.

attributes.name: http.request.method

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.brief: HTTP request method.
attributes.note:
HTTP request method value SHOULD be "known" to the instrumentation.
By default, this convention defines "known" methods as the ones listed in [RFC9110](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-methods)
and the PATCH method defined in [RFC5789](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5789.html).

If the HTTP request method is not known to instrumentation, it MUST set the `http.request.method` attribute to `_OTHER`.

If the HTTP instrumentation could end up converting valid HTTP request methods to `_OTHER`, then it MUST provide a way to override
the list of known HTTP methods. If this override is done via environment variable, then the environment variable MUST be named
OTEL_INSTRUMENTATION_HTTP_KNOWN_METHODS and support a comma-separated list of case-sensitive known HTTP methods
(this list MUST be a full override of the default known method, it is not a list of known methods in addition to the defaults).

HTTP method names are case-sensitive and `http.request.method` attribute value MUST match a known HTTP method name exactly.
Instrumentations for specific web frameworks that consider HTTP methods to be case insensitive, SHOULD populate a canonical equivalent.
Tracing instrumentations that do so, MUST also set `http.request.method_original` to the original value.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Name of the local HTTP server that received the request.
attributes.note: See [Setting `server.address` and `server.port` attributes](/docs/http/http-spans.md#setting-serveraddress-and-serverport-attributes).

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Port of the local HTTP server that received the request.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If `server.address` is set.

attributes.note: See [Setting `server.address` and `server.port` attributes](/docs/http/http-spans.md#setting-serveraddress-and-serverport-attributes).

groups.brief: An operating system process.

attributes.name: process.pid
attributes.brief: Process identifier (PID).

attributes.name: process.parent_pid
attributes.brief: Parent Process identifier (PPID).

attributes.name: process.owner
attributes.brief: The username of the user that owns the process.

attributes.name: process.executable.name
attributes.brief: The name of the process executable. On Linux based systems, can be set to the `Name` in `proc/[pid]/status`. On Windows, can be set to the base name of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: See [Selecting process attributes](#selecting-process-attributes) for details.

attributes.name: process.executable.path
attributes.brief: The full path to the process executable. On Linux based systems, can be set to the target of `proc/[pid]/exe`. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: See [Selecting process attributes](#selecting-process-attributes) for details.

attributes.name: process.command
attributes.brief: The command used to launch the process (i.e. the command name). On Linux based systems, can be set to the zeroth string in `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. On Windows, can be set to the first parameter extracted from `GetCommandLineW`.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: See [Selecting process attributes](#selecting-process-attributes) for details.

attributes.name: process.command_line
attributes.brief: The full command used to launch the process as a single string representing the full command. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetCommandLineW`. Do not set this if you have to assemble it just for monitoring; use `process.command_args` instead.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: See [Selecting process attributes](#selecting-process-attributes) for details.

attributes.name: process.command_args
attributes.brief: All the command arguments (including the command/executable itself) as received by the process. On Linux-based systems (and some other Unixoid systems supporting procfs), can be set according to the list of null-delimited strings extracted from `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. For libc-based executables, this would be the full argv vector passed to `main`.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: See [Selecting process attributes](#selecting-process-attributes) for details.

groups.brief: The single (language) runtime instance which is monitored.

attributes.name: process.runtime.name
attributes.brief: The name of the runtime of this process. For compiled native binaries, this SHOULD be the name of the compiler.

attributes.name: process.runtime.version
attributes.brief: The version of the runtime of this process, as returned by the runtime without modification.

attributes.name: process.runtime.description
attributes.brief: An additional description about the runtime of the process, for example a specific vendor customization of the runtime environment.
attributes.examples: Eclipse OpenJ9 Eclipse OpenJ9 VM openj9-0.21.0

groups.brief: The Android platform on which the Android application is running.

attributes.name: android.os.api_level
attributes.brief: Uniquely identifies the framework API revision offered by a version (`os.version`) of the android operating system. More information can be found [here](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/uses-sdk-element#ApiLevels).

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for software deployments.

attributes.name: deployment.environment
attributes.brief: Name of the [deployment environment](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_environment) (aka deployment tier).
attributes.note:
`deployment.environment` does not affect the uniqueness constraints defined through
the `service.namespace`, `service.name` and `service.instance.id` resource attributes.
This implies that resources carrying the following attribute combinations MUST be
considered to be identifying the same service:

* `service.name=frontend`, `deployment.environment=production`
* `service.name=frontend`, `deployment.environment=staging`.

groups.brief: This document defines the attributes used to describe the packaged software running the application code.

attributes.name: webengine.name
attributes.brief: The name of the web engine.

attributes.name: webengine.version
attributes.brief: The version of the web engine.

attributes.name: webengine.description
attributes.brief: Additional description of the web engine (e.g. detailed version and edition information).

groups.brief: Attributes for Google Cloud
Attributes for Google Cloud client libraries.

attributes.name: gcp.client.service
attributes.brief: Identifies the Google Cloud service for which the official client library is intended.
attributes.note: Intended to be a stable identifier for Google Cloud client libraries that is uniform across implementation languages. The value should be derived from the canonical service domain for the service; for example, 'foo.googleapis.com' should result in a value of 'foo'.

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for Google Cloud Run.

attributes.name: gcp.cloud_run.job.execution
attributes.brief: The name of the Cloud Run [execution](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/managing/job-executions) being run for the Job, as set by the [`CLOUD_RUN_EXECUTION`](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/container-contract#jobs-env-vars) environment variable.

attributes.name: gcp.cloud_run.job.task_index
attributes.brief: The index for a task within an execution as provided by the [`CLOUD_RUN_TASK_INDEX`](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/container-contract#jobs-env-vars) environment variable.

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for Google Compute Engine (GCE).

attributes.name: gcp.gce.instance.name
attributes.brief: The instance name of a GCE instance. This is the value provided by `host.name`, the visible name of the instance in the Cloud Console UI, and the prefix for the default hostname of the instance as defined by the [default internal DNS name](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/internal-dns#instance-fully-qualified-domain-names).

attributes.name: gcp.gce.instance.hostname
attributes.brief: The hostname of a GCE instance. This is the full value of the default or [custom hostname](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/custom-hostname-vm).

groups.brief: Deprecated process attributes.

attributes.name: process.cpu.state
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `cpu.mode` instead.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used to describe the server in a connection-based network interaction where there is one side that initiates the connection (the client is the side that initiates the connection). This covers all TCP network interactions since TCP is connection-based and one side initiates the connection (an exception is made for peer-to-peer communication over TCP where the "user-facing" surface of the protocol / API doesn't expose a clear notion of client and server). This also covers UDP network interactions where one side initiates the interaction, e.g. QUIC (HTTP/3) and DNS.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.address` SHOULD represent the server address behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

groups.brief: A container instance.

attributes.name: container.name
attributes.brief: Container name used by container runtime.

attributes.name: container.id
attributes.brief: Container ID. Usually a UUID, as for example used to [identify Docker containers](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/run/#container-identification). The UUID might be abbreviated.

attributes.name: container.runtime
attributes.brief: The container runtime managing this container.

attributes.name: container.image.name
attributes.brief: Name of the image the container was built on.

attributes.name: container.image.tags
attributes.brief: Container image tags. An example can be found in [Docker Image Inspect](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Image/operation/ImageInspect). Should be only the `<tag>` section of the full name for example from `registry.example.com/my-org/my-image:<tag>`.

attributes.name: container.image.id
attributes.brief: Runtime specific image identifier. Usually a hash algorithm followed by a UUID.
attributes.note:
Docker defines a sha256 of the image id; `container.image.id` corresponds to the `Image` field from the Docker container inspect [API](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Container/operation/ContainerInspect) endpoint.
K8s defines a link to the container registry repository with digest `"imageID": "registry.azurecr.io /namespace/service/dockerfile@sha256:bdeabd40c3a8a492eaf9e8e44d0ebbb84bac7ee25ac0cf8a7159d25f62555625"`.
The ID is assigned by the container runtime and can vary in different environments. Consider using `oci.manifest.digest` if it is important to identify the same image in different environments/runtimes.

attributes.name: container.image.repo_digests
attributes.brief: Repo digests of the container image as provided by the container runtime.
attributes.note: [Docker](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Image/operation/ImageInspect) and [CRI](https://github.com/kubernetes/cri-api/blob/c75ef5b473bbe2d0a4fc92f82235efd665ea8e9f/pkg/apis/runtime/v1/api.proto#L1237-L1238) report those under the `RepoDigests` field.

attributes.name: container.command
attributes.brief: The command used to run the container (i.e. the command name).
attributes.note: If using embedded credentials or sensitive data, it is recommended to remove them to prevent potential leakage.

attributes.name: container.command_line
attributes.brief: The full command run by the container as a single string representing the full command. [2]

attributes.name: container.command_args
attributes.brief: All the command arguments (including the command/executable itself) run by the container. [2]

attributes.name: container.label
attributes.brief: Container labels, `<key>` being the label name, the value being the label value.

groups.brief: This semantic convention describes an instance of a function that runs without provisioning or managing of servers (also known as serverless functions or Function as a Service (FaaS)) with spans.

attributes.name: cloud.resource_id
attributes.brief: Cloud provider-specific native identifier of the monitored cloud resource (e.g. an [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html) on AWS, a [fully qualified resource ID](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) on Azure, a [full resource name](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/resource_names#full_resource_name) on GCP)
attributes.note:
On some cloud providers, it may not be possible to determine the full ID at startup,
so it may be necessary to set `cloud.resource_id` as a span attribute instead.

The exact value to use for `cloud.resource_id` depends on the cloud provider.
The following well-known definitions MUST be used if you set this attribute and they apply:

* **AWS Lambda:** The function [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html).
  Take care not to use the "invoked ARN" directly but replace any
  [alias suffix](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-aliases.html)
  with the resolved function version, as the same runtime instance may be invocable with
  multiple different aliases.
* **GCP:** The [URI of the resource](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/full-resource-names)
* **Azure:** The [Fully Qualified Resource ID](https://docs.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) of the invoked function,
  *not* the function app, having the form
  `/subscriptions/<SUBSCIPTION_GUID>/resourceGroups/<RG>/providers/Microsoft.Web/sites/<FUNCAPP>/functions/<FUNC>`.
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider.

attributes.name: faas.invocation_id
attributes.brief: The invocation ID of the current function invocation.

attributes.name: faas.trigger

members.brief: A response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write
To provide an answer to an inbound HTTP request
A function is set to be executed when messages are sent to a messaging system
A function is scheduled to be executed regularly
If none of the others apply

attributes.brief: Type of the trigger which caused this function invocation.
attributes.note:
For the server/consumer span on the incoming side,
`faas.trigger` MUST be set.

Clients invoking FaaS instances usually cannot set `faas.trigger`,
since they would typically need to look in the payload to determine
the event type. If clients set it, it should be the same as the
trigger that corresponding incoming would have (i.e., this has
nothing to do with the underlying transport used to make the API
call to invoke the lambda, which is often HTTP).

groups.brief: Semantic Convention for FaaS triggered as a response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write.

attributes.name: faas.document.time
attributes.brief: A string containing the time when the data was accessed in the [ISO 8601](https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html) format expressed in [UTC](https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime).

attributes.name: faas.document.name
attributes.brief: The document name/table subjected to the operation. For example, in Cloud Storage or S3 is the name of the file, and in Cosmos DB the table name.

attributes.name: faas.document.collection
attributes.brief: The name of the source on which the triggering operation was performed. For example, in Cloud Storage or S3 corresponds to the bucket name, and in Cosmos DB to the database name.

attributes.name: faas.document.operation

members.brief: When a new object is created.

attributes.brief: Describes the type of the operation that was performed on the data.

groups.brief: Semantic Convention for FaaS triggered as a response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write.
Semantic Convention for FaaS set to be executed when messages are sent to a messaging system.
Semantic Convention for FaaS scheduled to be executed regularly.

attributes.name: faas.time
attributes.brief: A string containing the function invocation time in the [ISO 8601](https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html) format expressed in [UTC](https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime).

attributes.name: faas.cron
attributes.brief: A string containing the schedule period as [Cron Expression](https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E12058_01/doc/doc.1014/e12030/cron_expressions.htm).

groups.brief: Contains additional attributes for incoming FaaS spans.

attributes.name: faas.coldstart
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the serverless function is executed for the first time (aka cold-start).

attributes.name: faas.trigger

members.brief: A response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write
To provide an answer to an inbound HTTP request
A function is set to be executed when messages are sent to a messaging system
A function is scheduled to be executed regularly
If none of the others apply

attributes.brief: Type of the trigger which caused this function invocation.
attributes.note:
For the server/consumer span on the incoming side,
`faas.trigger` MUST be set.

Clients invoking FaaS instances usually cannot set `faas.trigger`,
since they would typically need to look in the payload to determine
the event type. If clients set it, it should be the same as the
trigger that corresponding incoming would have (i.e., this has
nothing to do with the underlying transport used to make the API
call to invoke the lambda, which is often HTTP).

groups.brief: Contains additional attributes for outgoing FaaS spans.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_name
attributes.brief: The name of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `faas.name` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_provider
attributes.brief: The cloud provider of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.provider` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_region
attributes.brief: The cloud region of the invoked function.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: For some cloud providers, like AWS or GCP, the region in which a function is hosted is essential to uniquely identify the function and also part of its endpoint. Since it's part of the endpoint being called, the region is always known to clients. In these cases, `faas.invoked_region` MUST be set accordingly. If the region is unknown to the client or not required for identifying the invoked function, setting `faas.invoked_region` is optional.

attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.region` resource attribute of the invoked function.

groups.brief: Common cross-signal messaging attributes.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

groups.brief:
Session is defined as the period of time encompassing all activities performed by the application and the actions executed by the end user.
Consequently, a Session is represented as a collection of Logs, Events, and Spans emitted by the Client Application throughout the Session's duration. Each Session is assigned a unique identifier, which is included as an attribute in the Logs, Events, and Spans generated during the Session's lifecycle.
When a session reaches end of life, typically due to user inactivity or session timeout, a new session identifier will be assigned. The previous session identifier may be provided by the instrumentation so that telemetry backends can link the two sessions.

attributes.brief: The previous `session.id` for this user, when known.

groups.brief: Attributes describing URL.

attributes.name: url.fragment
attributes.brief: The [URI fragment](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.5) component

attributes.name: url.path
attributes.brief: The [URI path](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.3) component
attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.path` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.

attributes.name: url.full
attributes.brief: Absolute URL describing a network resource according to [RFC3986](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986)
attributes.note:
For network calls, URL usually has `scheme://host[:port][path][?query][#fragment]` format, where the fragment is not transmitted over HTTP, but if it is known, it SHOULD be included nevertheless.
`url.full` MUST NOT contain credentials passed via URL in form of `https://username:password@www.example.com/`. In such case username and password SHOULD be redacted and attribute's value SHOULD be `https://REDACTED:REDACTED@www.example.com/`.
`url.full` SHOULD capture the absolute URL when it is available (or can be reconstructed). Sensitive content provided in `url.full` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.query
attributes.brief: The [URI query](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.4) component
attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.query` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

groups.brief: A Kubernetes Cluster.

attributes.name: k8s.cluster.name
attributes.brief: The name of the cluster.

attributes.name: k8s.cluster.uid
attributes.brief: A pseudo-ID for the cluster, set to the UID of the `kube-system` namespace.
attributes.note:
K8s doesn't have support for obtaining a cluster ID. If this is ever
added, we will recommend collecting the `k8s.cluster.uid` through the
official APIs. In the meantime, we are able to use the `uid` of the
`kube-system` namespace as a proxy for cluster ID. Read on for the
rationale.

Every object created in a K8s cluster is assigned a distinct UID. The
`kube-system` namespace is used by Kubernetes itself and will exist
for the lifetime of the cluster. Using the `uid` of the `kube-system`
namespace is a reasonable proxy for the K8s ClusterID as it will only
change if the cluster is rebuilt. Furthermore, Kubernetes UIDs are
UUIDs as standardized by
[ISO/IEC 9834-8 and ITU-T X.667](https://www.itu.int/ITU-T/studygroups/com17/oid.html).
Which states:

> If generated according to one of the mechanisms defined in Rec.
  ITU-T X.667 | ISO/IEC 9834-8, a UUID is either guaranteed to be
  different from all other UUIDs generated before 3603 A.D., or is
  extremely likely to be different (depending on the mechanism chosen).

Therefore, UIDs between clusters should be extremely unlikely to
conflict.

attributes.brief: Parent Process identifier (PPID).

attributes.name: process.vpid
attributes.brief: Virtual process identifier.
attributes.note: The process ID within a PID namespace. This is not necessarily unique across all processes on the host but it is unique within the process namespace that the process exists within.

attributes.name: process.session_leader.pid
attributes.brief: The PID of the process's session leader. This is also the session ID (SID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.group_leader.pid
attributes.brief: The PID of the process's group leader. This is also the process group ID (PGID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.executable.name
attributes.brief: The name of the process executable. On Linux based systems, can be set to the `Name` in `proc/[pid]/status`. On Windows, can be set to the base name of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

attributes.name: process.executable.path
attributes.brief: The full path to the process executable. On Linux based systems, can be set to the target of `proc/[pid]/exe`. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

attributes.name: process.command
attributes.brief: The command used to launch the process (i.e. the command name). On Linux based systems, can be set to the zeroth string in `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. On Windows, can be set to the first parameter extracted from `GetCommandLineW`.

attributes.name: process.command_line
attributes.brief: The full command used to launch the process as a single string representing the full command. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetCommandLineW`. Do not set this if you have to assemble it just for monitoring; use `process.command_args` instead.

attributes.name: process.command_args
attributes.brief: All the command arguments (including the command/executable itself) as received by the process. On Linux-based systems (and some other Unixoid systems supporting procfs), can be set according to the list of null-delimited strings extracted from `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. For libc-based executables, this would be the full argv vector passed to `main`.

attributes.note:
The OpenTelemetry SDK MUST set the `telemetry.sdk.name` attribute to `opentelemetry`.
If another SDK, like a fork or a vendor-provided implementation, is used, this SDK MUST set the
`telemetry.sdk.name` attribute to the fully-qualified class or module name of this SDK's main entry point
or another suitable identifier depending on the language.
The identifier `opentelemetry` is reserved and MUST NOT be used in this case.
All custom identifiers SHOULD be stable across different versions of an implementation.

attributes.name: http.scheme
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `url.scheme` instead.

attributes.name: http.url
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `url.full` instead.

attributes.name: http.target
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `url.path` and `url.query` instead.

attributes.name: http.request_content_length
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `http.request.header.content-length` instead.

attributes.name: http.response_content_length
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `http.response.header.content-length` instead.

attributes.name: http.client_ip
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `client.address` instead.

attributes.name: http.host
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use one of `server.address`, `client.address` or `http.request.header.host` instead, depending on the usage.
attributes.deprecated: Replaced by one of `server.address`, `client.address` or `http.request.header.host`, depending on the usage.

attributes.name: http.request_content_length_uncompressed
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `http.request.body.size` instead.

attributes.name: http.response_content_length_uncompressed
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `http.response.body.size` instead.

attributes.name: http.server_name
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `server.address` instead.

attributes.name: http.flavor
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `network.protocol.name` instead.

attributes.name: http.user_agent
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `user_agent.original` instead.
examples: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 14_7_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/14.1.2 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1

groups.brief: These attributes allow to report this unit of code and therefore to provide more context about the span.

attributes.name: code.function
attributes.brief: The method or function name, or equivalent (usually rightmost part of the code unit's name).

attributes.name: code.namespace
attributes.brief: The "namespace" within which `code.function` is defined. Usually the qualified class or module name, such that `code.namespace` + some separator + `code.function` form a unique identifier for the code unit.

attributes.name: code.filepath
attributes.brief: The source code file name that identifies the code unit as uniquely as possible (preferably an absolute file path).

attributes.name: code.lineno
attributes.brief: The line number in `code.filepath` best representing the operation. It SHOULD point within the code unit named in `code.function`.

attributes.name: code.column
attributes.brief: The column number in `code.filepath` best representing the operation. It SHOULD point within the code unit named in `code.function`.

attributes.name: code.stacktrace
attributes.brief: A stacktrace as a string in the natural representation for the language runtime. The representation is to be determined and documented by each language SIG.

groups.brief: This document defines semantic conventions for remote procedure calls.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: RPC server [host name](https://grpc.github.io/grpc/core/md_doc_naming.html).
attributes.note: May contain server IP address, DNS name, or local socket name. When host component is an IP address, instrumentations SHOULD NOT do a reverse proxy lookup to obtain DNS name and SHOULD set `server.address` to the IP address provided in the host component.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if the port is supported by the network transport used for communication.

attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: rpc.method
attributes.brief: The name of the (logical) method being called, must be equal to the $method part in the span name.
attributes.note: This is the logical name of the method from the RPC interface perspective, which can be different from the name of any implementing method/function. The `code.function` attribute may be used to store the latter (e.g., method actually executing the call on the server side, RPC client stub method on the client side).

attributes.name: rpc.service
attributes.brief: The full (logical) name of the service being called, including its package name, if applicable.
attributes.note: This is the logical name of the service from the RPC interface perspective, which can be different from the name of any implementing class. The `code.namespace` attribute may be used to store the latter (despite the attribute name, it may include a class name; e.g., class with method actually executing the call on the server side, RPC client stub class on the client side).

attributes.name: rpc.system
attributes.brief: A string identifying the remoting system. See below for a list of well-known identifiers.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

attributes.name: network.type
attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://osi-model.com/network-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.peer.address

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).

attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://osi-model.com/network-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

attributes.name: rpc.jsonrpc.error_code
attributes.brief: `error.code` property of response if it is an error response.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If response is not successful.

attributes.name: rpc.jsonrpc.error_message
attributes.brief: `error.message` property of response if it is an error response.

attributes.name: rpc.jsonrpc.request_id
attributes.brief: `id` property of request or response. Since protocol allows id to be int, string, `null` or missing (for notifications), value is expected to be cast to string for simplicity. Use empty string in case of `null` value. Omit entirely if this is a notification.

attributes.name: rpc.jsonrpc.version
attributes.brief: Protocol version as in `jsonrpc` property of request/response. Since JSON-RPC 1.0 doesn't specify this, the value can be omitted.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If other than the default version (`1.0`)

attributes.name: rpc.method
attributes.brief: The name of the (logical) method being called, must be equal to the $method part in the span name.
attributes.note: This is always required for jsonrpc. See the note in the general RPC conventions for more information.

groups.brief: RPC received/sent message.

attributes.name: rpc.message.type
attributes.brief: Whether this is a received or sent message.

attributes.name: rpc.message.id
attributes.brief: MUST be calculated as two different counters starting from `1` one for sent messages and one for received message.
attributes.note: This way we guarantee that the values will be consistent between different implementations.

attributes.name: rpc.message.compressed_size
attributes.brief: Compressed size of the message in bytes.

attributes.name: rpc.message.uncompressed_size
attributes.brief: Uncompressed size of the message in bytes.

groups.brief: The telemetry SDK used to capture data recorded by the instrumentation libraries.

attributes.name: telemetry.sdk.name
attributes.brief: The name of the telemetry SDK as defined above.
attributes.note:
The OpenTelemetry SDK MUST set the `telemetry.sdk.name` attribute to `opentelemetry`.
If another SDK, like a fork or a vendor-provided implementation, is used, this SDK MUST set the
`telemetry.sdk.name` attribute to the fully-qualified class or module name of this SDK's main entry point
or another suitable identifier depending on the language.
The identifier `opentelemetry` is reserved and MUST NOT be used in this case.
All custom identifiers SHOULD be stable across different versions of an implementation.

attributes.name: telemetry.sdk.language
attributes.brief: The language of the telemetry SDK.

attributes.name: telemetry.sdk.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the telemetry SDK.

groups.brief: The Android platform on which the Android application is running.

attributes.name: android.os.api_level
attributes.brief: Uniquely identifies the framework API revision offered by a version (`os.version`) of the android operating system. More information can be found [here](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/uses-sdk-element#ApiLevels).

groups.brief: The telemetry SDK used to capture data recorded by the instrumentation libraries.

attributes.name: telemetry.distro.name
attributes.brief: The name of the auto instrumentation agent or distribution, if used.
attributes.note:
Official auto instrumentation agents and distributions SHOULD set the `telemetry.distro.name` attribute to
a string starting with `opentelemetry-`, e.g. `opentelemetry-java-instrumentation`.

attributes.name: telemetry.distro.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the auto instrumentation agent or distribution, if used.

groups.brief: A host is defined as a computing instance. For example, physical servers, virtual machines, switches or disk array.

attributes.name: host.id
attributes.brief: Unique host ID. For Cloud, this must be the instance_id assigned by the cloud provider. For non-containerized systems, this should be the `machine-id`. See the table below for the sources to use to determine the `machine-id` based on operating system.

attributes.name: host.name
attributes.brief: Name of the host. On Unix systems, it may contain what the hostname command returns, or the fully qualified hostname, or another name specified by the user.

attributes.name: host.type
attributes.brief: Type of host. For Cloud, this must be the machine type.

attributes.name: host.arch
attributes.brief: The CPU architecture the host system is running on.

attributes.name: host.image.name
attributes.brief: Name of the VM image or OS install the host was instantiated from.

attributes.name: host.image.id
attributes.brief: VM image ID or host OS image ID. For Cloud, this value is from the provider.

attributes.name: host.image.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the VM image or host OS as defined in [Version Attributes](/docs/resource/README.md#version-attributes).

attributes.name: host.ip
attributes.brief: Available IP addresses of the host, excluding loopback interfaces.
attributes.note: IPv4 Addresses MUST be specified in dotted-quad notation. IPv6 addresses MUST be specified in the [RFC 5952](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5952.html) format.

attributes.name: host.mac
attributes.brief: Available MAC addresses of the host, excluding loopback interfaces.
attributes.note: MAC Addresses MUST be represented in [IEEE RA hexadecimal form](https://standards.ieee.org/wp-content/uploads/import/documents/tutorials/eui.pdf): as hyphen-separated octets in uppercase hexadecimal form from most to least significant.

groups.brief: A host's CPU information

attributes.name: host.cpu.vendor.id
attributes.brief: Processor manufacturer identifier. A maximum 12-character string.
attributes.note: [CPUID](https://wiki.osdev.org/CPUID) command returns the vendor ID string in EBX, EDX and ECX registers. Writing these to memory in this order results in a 12-character string.

attributes.name: host.cpu.family
attributes.brief: Family or generation of the CPU.

attributes.name: host.cpu.model.id
attributes.brief: Model identifier. It provides more granular information about the CPU, distinguishing it from other CPUs within the same family.

attributes.name: host.cpu.model.name
attributes.brief: Model designation of the processor.

attributes.name: host.cpu.stepping
attributes.brief: Stepping or core revisions.

attributes.name: host.cpu.cache.l2.size
attributes.brief: The amount of level 2 memory cache available to the processor (in Bytes).

groups.brief: This document defines the shared attributes used to report an error.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.
attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

groups.brief: Describes user-agent attributes.

attributes.name: user_agent.original
attributes.brief: Value of the [HTTP User-Agent](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.user-agent) header sent by the client.
examples: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 14_7_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/14.1.2 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1

attributes.name: user_agent.name
attributes.brief: Name of the user-agent extracted from original. Usually refers to the browser's name.
attributes.note: [Example](https://www.whatsmyua.info) of extracting browser's name from original string. In the case of using a user-agent for non-browser products, such as microservices with multiple names/versions inside the `user_agent.original`, the most significant name SHOULD be selected. In such a scenario it should align with `user_agent.version`

attributes.name: user_agent.version
attributes.brief: Version of the user-agent extracted from original. Usually refers to the browser's version
attributes.note: [Example](https://www.whatsmyua.info) of extracting browser's version from original string. In the case of using a user-agent for non-browser products, such as microservices with multiple names/versions inside the `user_agent.original`, the most significant version SHOULD be selected. In such a scenario it should align with `user_agent.name`

groups.brief: A cloud environment (e.g. GCP, Azure, AWS).

attributes.name: cloud.provider
attributes.brief: Name of the cloud provider.

attributes.name: cloud.account.id
attributes.brief: The cloud account ID the resource is assigned to.

attributes.name: cloud.region
attributes.brief: The geographical region the resource is running.
attributes.note: Refer to your provider's docs to see the available regions, for example [Alibaba Cloud regions](https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/doc-detail/40654.htm), [AWS regions](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/regions_az/), [Azure regions](https://azure.microsoft.com/global-infrastructure/geographies/), [Google Cloud regions](https://cloud.google.com/about/locations), or [Tencent Cloud regions](https://www.tencentcloud.com/document/product/213/6091).

attributes.name: cloud.resource_id
attributes.brief: Cloud provider-specific native identifier of the monitored cloud resource (e.g. an [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html) on AWS, a [fully qualified resource ID](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) on Azure, a [full resource name](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/resource_names#full_resource_name) on GCP)
attributes.note:
On some cloud providers, it may not be possible to determine the full ID at startup,
so it may be necessary to set `cloud.resource_id` as a span attribute instead.

The exact value to use for `cloud.resource_id` depends on the cloud provider.
The following well-known definitions MUST be used if you set this attribute and they apply:

* **AWS Lambda:** The function [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html).
  Take care not to use the "invoked ARN" directly but replace any
  [alias suffix](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-aliases.html)
  with the resolved function version, as the same runtime instance may be invocable with
  multiple different aliases.
* **GCP:** The [URI of the resource](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/full-resource-names)
* **Azure:** The [Fully Qualified Resource ID](https://docs.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) of the invoked function,
  *not* the function app, having the form
  `/subscriptions/<SUBSCIPTION_GUID>/resourceGroups/<RG>/providers/Microsoft.Web/sites/<FUNCAPP>/functions/<FUNC>`.
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider.

attributes.name: cloud.availability_zone
attributes.brief: Cloud regions often have multiple, isolated locations known as zones to increase availability. Availability zone represents the zone where the resource is running.
attributes.note: Availability zones are called "zones" on Alibaba Cloud and Google Cloud.

attributes.name: cloud.platform

members.brief: Red Hat OpenShift on Alibaba Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on Google Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud

attributes.brief: The cloud platform in use.
attributes.note: The prefix of the service SHOULD match the one specified in `cloud.provider`.

groups.brief: This document defines log attributes

attributes.name: log.iostream
attributes.brief: The stream associated with the log. See below for a list of well-known values.

groups.brief: Attributes for a file to which log was emitted.

attributes.name: log.file.name
attributes.brief: The basename of the file.

attributes.name: log.file.path
attributes.brief: The full path to the file.

attributes.name: log.file.name_resolved
attributes.brief: The basename of the file, with symlinks resolved.

attributes.name: log.file.path_resolved
attributes.brief: The full path to the file, with symlinks resolved.

groups.brief: This document defines the generic attributes that may be used in any Log Record.

attributes.name: log.record.uid
attributes.brief: A unique identifier for the Log Record.
attributes.note:
If an id is provided, other log records with the same id will be considered duplicates and can be removed safely. This means, that two distinguishable log records MUST have different values.
The id MAY be an [Universally Unique Lexicographically Sortable Identifier (ULID)](https://github.com/ulid/spec), but other identifiers (e.g. UUID) may be used as needed.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used for any network related operation.

attributes.name: network.local.address
attributes.brief: Local address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.local.port
attributes.brief: Local port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://osi-model.com/application-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

attributes.name: network.type
attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://osi-model.com/network-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used for any network related operation.

attributes.name: network.carrier.icc
attributes.brief: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 2-character country code associated with the mobile carrier network.

attributes.name: network.carrier.mcc
attributes.brief: The mobile carrier country code.

attributes.name: network.carrier.mnc
attributes.brief: The mobile carrier network code.

attributes.name: network.carrier.name
attributes.brief: The name of the mobile carrier.

attributes.name: network.connection.subtype
attributes.brief: This describes more details regarding the connection.type. It may be the type of cell technology connection, but it could be used for describing details about a wifi connection.

attributes.name: network.connection.type
attributes.brief: The internet connection type.

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for exceptions represented using Log Records.

attributes.name: exception.stacktrace
attributes.brief: A stacktrace as a string in the natural representation for the language runtime. The representation is to be determined and documented by each language SIG.
attributes.examples:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Test exception
 at com.example.GenerateTrace.methodB(GenerateTrace.java:13)
 at com.example.GenerateTrace.methodA(GenerateTrace.java:9)
 at com.example.GenerateTrace.main(GenerateTrace.java:5)

attributes.name: exception.type
attributes.brief: The type of the exception (its fully-qualified class name, if applicable). The dynamic type of the exception should be preferred over the static type in languages that support it.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: Required if `exception.message` is not set, recommended otherwise.

attributes.name: exception.message
attributes.brief: The exception message.
examples: Can't convert 'int' object to str implicitly

requirement_level.conditionally_required: Required if `exception.type` is not set, recommended otherwise.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

requirement_level.recommended: if the transport is `tcp` or `udp`

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

groups.brief: Number of TLS handshakes that are currently in progress on the server.
groups.note: Meter name: `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel`; Added in: ASP.NET Core 8.0

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.address` SHOULD represent the server address behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: network.type
attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://osi-model.com/network-layer/) or non-OSI equivalent.

requirement_level.recommended: if the transport is `tcp` or `udp`

attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://osi-model.com/transport-layer/) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

groups.brief: Resources used by Google Compute Engine (GCE).

attributes.name: gcp.gce.instance.name
attributes.brief: The instance name of a GCE instance. This is the value provided by `host.name`, the visible name of the instance in the Cloud Console UI, and the prefix for the default hostname of the instance as defined by the [default internal DNS name](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/internal-dns#instance-fully-qualified-domain-names).

attributes.name: gcp.gce.instance.hostname
attributes.brief: The hostname of a GCE instance. This is the full value of the default or [custom hostname](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/custom-hostname-vm).

attributes.name: jvm.thread.daemon
attributes.brief: Whether the thread is daemon or not.

attributes.name: jvm.thread.state

members.brief: A thread that has not yet started is in this state.
A thread executing in the Java virtual machine is in this state.
A thread that is blocked waiting for a monitor lock is in this state.
A thread that is waiting indefinitely for another thread to perform a particular action is in this state.
A thread that is waiting for another thread to perform an action for up to a specified waiting time is in this state.
A thread that has exited is in this state.

groups.brief: Attributes describing URL.

attributes.name: url.domain
attributes.brief: Domain extracted from the `url.full`, such as "opentelemetry.io".
attributes.note: In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the domain field. If the URL contains a [literal IPv6 address](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2732#section-2) enclosed by `[` and `]`, the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the domain field.

attributes.name: url.extension
attributes.brief: The file extension extracted from the `url.full`, excluding the leading dot.
attributes.note: The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension. When the file name has multiple extensions `example.tar.gz`, only the last one should be captured `gz`, not `tar.gz`.

attributes.name: url.fragment
attributes.brief: The [URI fragment](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.5) component

attributes.name: url.full
attributes.brief: Absolute URL describing a network resource according to [RFC3986](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986)
attributes.note:
For network calls, URL usually has `scheme://host[:port][path][?query][#fragment]` format, where the fragment is not transmitted over HTTP, but if it is known, it SHOULD be included nevertheless.
`url.full` MUST NOT contain credentials passed via URL in form of `https://username:password@www.example.com/`. In such case username and password SHOULD be redacted and attribute's value SHOULD be `https://REDACTED:REDACTED@www.example.com/`.
`url.full` SHOULD capture the absolute URL when it is available (or can be reconstructed). Sensitive content provided in `url.full` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.original
attributes.brief: Unmodified original URL as seen in the event source.
attributes.note:
In network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path. This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.
`url.original` might contain credentials passed via URL in form of `https://username:password@www.example.com/`. In such case password and username SHOULD NOT be redacted and attribute's value SHOULD remain the same.

attributes.name: url.path
attributes.brief: The [URI path](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.3) component
attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.path` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.port
attributes.brief: Port extracted from the `url.full`

attributes.name: url.query
attributes.brief: The [URI query](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.4) component
attributes.note: Sensitive content provided in `url.query` SHOULD be scrubbed when instrumentations can identify it.

attributes.name: url.registered_domain
attributes.brief: The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
attributes.note: This value can be determined precisely with the [public suffix list](http://publicsuffix.org). For example, the registered domain for `foo.example.com` is `example.com`. Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as `co.uk`.

attributes.name: url.scheme
attributes.brief: The [URI scheme](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.1) component identifying the used protocol.

attributes.name: url.subdomain
attributes.brief: The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain. In a partially qualified domain, or if the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
attributes.note: The subdomain portion of `www.east.mydomain.co.uk` is `east`. If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as `sub2.sub1.example.com`, the subdomain field should contain `sub2.sub1`, with no trailing period.

attributes.name: url.template
attributes.brief: The low-cardinality template of an [absolute path reference](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-4.2).

attributes.name: url.top_level_domain
attributes.brief: The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is `com`.
attributes.note: This value can be determined precisely with the [public suffix list](http://publicsuffix.org).

groups.brief: Describes FaaS attributes.

attributes.name: faas.trigger

members.brief: A response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write
To provide an answer to an inbound HTTP request
A function is set to be executed when messages are sent to a messaging system
A function is scheduled to be executed regularly
If none of the others apply

attributes.brief: Type of the trigger which caused this function invocation.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_name
attributes.brief: The name of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `faas.name` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_provider
attributes.brief: The cloud provider of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.provider` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_region
attributes.brief: The cloud region of the invoked function.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: For some cloud providers, like AWS or GCP, the region in which a function is hosted is essential to uniquely identify the function and also part of its endpoint. Since it's part of the endpoint being called, the region is always known to clients. In these cases, `faas.invoked_region` MUST be set accordingly. If the region is unknown to the client or not required for identifying the invoked function, setting `faas.invoked_region` is optional.

attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.region` resource attribute of the invoked function.

groups.brief: Event loop minimum delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.min` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop maximum delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.max` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop mean delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.mean` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop standard deviation delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.stddev` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop 50 percentile delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.percentile(50)` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop 90 percentile delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.percentile(90)` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop 99 percentile delay.
groups.note: Value can be retrieved from value `histogram.percentile(99)` of [`perf_hooks.monitorEventLoopDelay([options])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooksmonitoreventloopdelayoptions)

groups.brief: Event loop utilization.
groups.note: The value range is [0.0,1.0] and can be retrieved from value [`performance.eventLoopUtilization([utilization1[, utilization2]])`](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#performanceeventlooputilizationutilization1-utilization2)

groups.brief: Common ASP.NET Core rate-limiting metrics attributes

attributes.name: aspnetcore.rate_limiting.policy
attributes.brief: Rate limiting policy name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if the matched endpoint for the request had a rate-limiting policy.

groups.brief: Number of requests that were attempted to be matched to an endpoint.
groups.note: Meter name: `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Routing`; Added in: ASP.NET Core 8.0

attributes.name: http.route
attributes.brief: The matched route, that is, the path template in the format used by the respective server framework.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if a route was successfully matched.

attributes.note:
MUST NOT be populated when this is not supported by the HTTP server framework as the route attribute should have low-cardinality and the URI path can NOT substitute it.
SHOULD include the [application root](/docs/http/http-spans.md#http-server-definitions) if there is one.

attributes.name: aspnetcore.routing.is_fallback
attributes.brief: A value that indicates whether the matched route is a fallback route.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if a route was successfully matched.

attributes.name: aspnetcore.routing.match_status
attributes.brief: Match result - success or failure

groups.brief: Number of exceptions caught by exception handling middleware.
groups.note: Meter name: `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Diagnostics`; Added in: ASP.NET Core 8.0

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: The full name of exception type.
attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

* Use a domain-specific attribute
* Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: aspnetcore.diagnostics.handler.type
attributes.brief: Full type name of the [`IExceptionHandler`](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.diagnostics.iexceptionhandler) implementation that handled the exception.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if the exception was handled by this handler.

attributes.name: aspnetcore.diagnostics.exception.result

members.brief: Exception was handled by the exception handling middleware.
Exception was not handled by the exception handling middleware.
Exception handling was skipped because the response had started.
Exception handling didn't run because the request was aborted.

attributes.brief: ASP.NET Core exception middleware handling result

attributes.name: aspnetcore.rate_limiting.policy

groups.brief: Kubernetes resource attributes.

attributes.name: k8s.cluster.name
attributes.brief: The name of the cluster.

attributes.name: k8s.cluster.uid
attributes.brief: A pseudo-ID for the cluster, set to the UID of the `kube-system` namespace.
attributes.note:
K8s doesn't have support for obtaining a cluster ID. If this is ever
added, we will recommend collecting the `k8s.cluster.uid` through the
official APIs. In the meantime, we are able to use the `uid` of the
`kube-system` namespace as a proxy for cluster ID. Read on for the
rationale.

Every object created in a K8s cluster is assigned a distinct UID. The
`kube-system` namespace is used by Kubernetes itself and will exist
for the lifetime of the cluster. Using the `uid` of the `kube-system`
namespace is a reasonable proxy for the K8s ClusterID as it will only
change if the cluster is rebuilt. Furthermore, Kubernetes UIDs are
UUIDs as standardized by
[ISO/IEC 9834-8 and ITU-T X.667](https://www.itu.int/ITU-T/studygroups/com17/oid.html).
Which states:

> If generated according to one of the mechanisms defined in Rec.
  ITU-T X.667 | ISO/IEC 9834-8, a UUID is either guaranteed to be
  different from all other UUIDs generated before 3603 A.D., or is
  extremely likely to be different (depending on the mechanism chosen).

Therefore, UIDs between clusters should be extremely unlikely to
conflict.

attributes.name: k8s.daemonset.name
attributes.brief: The name of the DaemonSet.

attributes.brief: The name of the Job.
