attributes.name: os.description
attributes.brief: Human readable (not intended to be parsed) OS version information, like e.g. reported by `ver` or `lsb_release -a` commands.

attributes.name: os.name
attributes.brief: Human readable operating system name.

attributes.name: os.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the operating system as defined in [Version Attributes](/docs/resource/README.md#version-attributes).

attributes.name: os.build_id
attributes.brief: Unique identifier for a particular build or compilation of the operating system.

attributes.name: os.type
attributes.brief: The operating system type.

groups.brief: The device on which the process represented by this resource is running.

attributes.name: device.id
attributes.brief: A unique identifier representing the device
attributes.note: The device identifier MUST only be defined using the values outlined below. This value is not an advertising identifier and MUST NOT be used as such. On iOS (Swift or Objective-C), this value MUST be equal to the [vendor identifier](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uidevice/1620059-identifierforvendor). On Android (Java or Kotlin), this value MUST be equal to the Firebase Installation ID or a globally unique UUID which is persisted across sessions in your application. More information can be found [here](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids) on best practices and exact implementation details. Caution should be taken when storing personal data or anything which can identify a user. GDPR and data protection laws may apply, ensure you do your own due diligence.

attributes.name: device.manufacturer
attributes.brief: The name of the device manufacturer
attributes.note: The Android OS provides this field via [Build](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build#MANUFACTURER). iOS apps SHOULD hardcode the value `Apple`.

attributes.name: device.model.identifier
attributes.brief: The model identifier for the device
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a machine-readable version of the model identifier rather than the market or consumer-friendly name of the device.

attributes.name: device.model.name
attributes.brief: The marketing name for the device model
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a human-readable version of the device model rather than a machine-readable alternative.

groups.brief: Resource describing the packaged software running the application code. Web engines are typically executed using process.runtime.

attributes.name: webengine.version
attributes.brief: The version of the web engine.

attributes.name: webengine.description
attributes.brief: Additional description of the web engine (e.g. detailed version and edition information).

attributes.name: webengine.name
attributes.brief: The name of the web engine.

groups.brief: A container instance.

attributes.name: container.name
attributes.brief: Container name used by container runtime.

attributes.name: container.id
attributes.brief: Container ID. Usually a UUID, as for example used to [identify Docker containers](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/run/#container-identification). The UUID might be abbreviated.

attributes.name: container.runtime
attributes.brief: The container runtime managing this container.

attributes.name: container.image.name
attributes.brief: Name of the image the container was built on.

attributes.name: container.image.tags
attributes.brief: Container image tags. An example can be found in [Docker Image Inspect](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Image/operation/ImageInspect). Should be only the `<tag>` section of the full name for example from `registry.example.com/my-org/my-image:<tag>`.

attributes.name: container.image.id
attributes.brief: Runtime specific image identifier. Usually a hash algorithm followed by a UUID.
attributes.note:
Docker defines a sha256 of the image id; `container.image.id` corresponds to the `Image` field from the Docker container inspect [API](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Container/operation/ContainerInspect) endpoint.
K8s defines a link to the container registry repository with digest `"imageID": "registry.azurecr.io /namespace/service/dockerfile@sha256:bdeabd40c3a8a492eaf9e8e44d0ebbb84bac7ee25ac0cf8a7159d25f62555625"`.
The ID is assigned by the container runtime and can vary in different environments. Consider using `oci.manifest.digest` if it is important to identify the same image in different environments/runtimes.

attributes.name: container.image.repo_digests
attributes.brief: Repo digests of the container image as provided by the container runtime.
attributes.note: [Docker](https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.43/#tag/Image/operation/ImageInspect) and [CRI](https://github.com/kubernetes/cri-api/blob/c75ef5b473bbe2d0a4fc92f82235efd665ea8e9f/pkg/apis/runtime/v1/api.proto#L1237-L1238) report those under the `RepoDigests` field.

attributes.name: container.label
attributes.brief: Container labels, `<key>` being the label name, the value being the label value.

attributes.name: oci.manifest.digest
attributes.brief: The digest of the OCI image manifest. For container images specifically is the digest by which the container image is known.
attributes.note:
Follows [OCI Image Manifest Specification](https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/main/manifest.md), and specifically the [Digest property](https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/main/descriptor.md#digests).
An example can be found in [Example Image Manifest](https://docs.docker.com/registry/spec/manifest-v2-2/#example-image-manifest).

attributes.name: container.command
attributes.brief: The command used to run the container (i.e. the command name).
attributes.note: If using embedded credentials or sensitive data, it is recommended to remove them to prevent potential leakage.

attributes.name: container.command_line
attributes.brief: The full command run by the container as a single string representing the full command. [2]

attributes.name: container.command_args
attributes.brief: All the command arguments (including the command/executable itself) run by the container. [2]

groups.brief: Attributes reserved for OpenTelemetry

attributes.name: otel.status_code

members.brief: The operation has been validated by an Application developer or Operator to have completed successfully.

attributes.brief: Name of the code, either "OK" or "ERROR". MUST NOT be set if the status code is UNSET.

attributes.name: otel.status_description
attributes.brief: Description of the Status if it has a value, otherwise not set.

groups.brief: Attributes used by non-OTLP exporters to represent OpenTelemetry Scope's concepts.

attributes.name: otel.scope.name
attributes.brief: The name of the instrumentation scope - (`InstrumentationScope.Name` in OTLP).

attributes.name: otel.scope.version
attributes.brief: The version of the instrumentation scope - (`InstrumentationScope.Version` in OTLP).

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for Feature Flags.

attributes.name: feature_flag.key
attributes.brief: The unique identifier of the feature flag.

attributes.name: feature_flag.provider_name
attributes.brief: The name of the service provider that performs the flag evaluation.

attributes.name: feature_flag.variant
attributes.brief: SHOULD be a semantic identifier for a value. If one is unavailable, a stringified version of the value can be used.
attributes.note:
A semantic identifier, commonly referred to as a variant, provides a means
for referring to a value without including the value itself. This can
provide additional context for understanding the meaning behind a value.
For example, the variant `red` maybe be used for the value `#c05543`.

A stringified version of the value can be used in situations where a
semantic identifier is unavailable. String representation of the value
should be determined by the implementer.

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for GraphQL.

attributes.name: graphql.operation.name
attributes.brief: The name of the operation being executed.

attributes.name: graphql.operation.type
attributes.brief: The type of the operation being executed.

attributes.name: graphql.document
attributes.brief: The GraphQL document being executed.
attributes.note: The value may be sanitized to exclude sensitive information.

groups.brief: Describes deprecated container attributes.

attributes.name: container.labels
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `container.label` instead.

attributes.name: container.cpu.state

members.brief: When tasks of the cgroup are in user mode (Linux). When all container processes are in user mode (Windows).
When CPU is used by the system (host OS)
When tasks of the cgroup are in kernel mode (Linux). When all container processes are in kernel mode (Windows).

attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `cpu.mode` instead.

groups.brief: Describes deprecated `gen_ai` attributes.

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.prompt_tokens
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `gen_ai.usage.input_tokens` instead.

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.completion_tokens
attributes.brief: Deprecated, use `gen_ai.usage.output_tokens` instead.

groups.brief: Describes file attributes.

attributes.name: file.directory
attributes.brief: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

attributes.name: file.extension
attributes.brief: File extension, excluding the leading dot.
attributes.note: When the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

attributes.name: file.name
attributes.brief: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

attributes.name: file.path
attributes.brief: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

attributes.name: file.size
attributes.brief: File size in bytes.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used for any disk related operation.

attributes.name: disk.io.direction
attributes.brief: The disk IO operation direction.

groups.brief: Describes information about the user.

attributes.name: user.email
attributes.brief: User email address.

attributes.name: user.full_name
attributes.brief: User's full name

attributes.name: user.hash
attributes.brief: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
attributes.note: Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

attributes.name: user.id
attributes.brief: Unique identifier of the user.

attributes.name: user.name
attributes.brief: Short name or login/username of the user.

attributes.name: user.roles
attributes.brief: Array of user roles at the time of the event.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used to describe the client in a connection-based network interaction where there is one side that initiates the connection (the client is the side that initiates the connection). This covers all TCP network interactions since TCP is connection-based and one side initiates the connection (an exception is made for peer-to-peer communication over TCP where the "user-facing" surface of the protocol / API doesn't expose a clear notion of client and server). This also covers UDP network interactions where one side initiates the interaction, e.g. QUIC (HTTP/3) and DNS.

attributes.name: client.address
attributes.brief: Client address - domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.
attributes.note: When observed from the server side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `client.address` SHOULD represent the client address behind any intermediaries,  for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: client.port
attributes.brief: Client port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the server side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `client.port` SHOULD represent the client port behind any intermediaries,  for example proxies, if it's available.

groups.brief: This document defines the attributes used to describe telemetry in the context of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) Models requests and responses.

attributes.name: gen_ai.system
attributes.brief: The Generative AI product as identified by the client or server instrumentation.
attributes.note:
The actual GenAI product may differ from the one identified by the client. For example, when using OpenAI client libraries to communicate with Mistral, the `gen_ai.system` is set to `openai` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.
For custom model, a custom friendly name SHOULD be used. If none of these options apply, the `gen_ai.system` SHOULD be set to `_OTHER`.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.model
attributes.brief: The name of the GenAI model a request is being made to.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.max_tokens
attributes.brief: The maximum number of tokens the model generates for a request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.temperature
attributes.brief: The temperature setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.top_p
attributes.brief: The top_p sampling setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.top_k
attributes.brief: The top_k sampling setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.stop_sequences
attributes.brief: List of sequences that the model will use to stop generating further tokens.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.frequency_penalty
attributes.brief: The frequency penalty setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.request.presence_penalty
attributes.brief: The presence penalty setting for the GenAI request.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.id
attributes.brief: The unique identifier for the completion.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.model
attributes.brief: The name of the model that generated the response.

attributes.name: gen_ai.response.finish_reasons
attributes.brief: Array of reasons the model stopped generating tokens, corresponding to each generation received.

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.input_tokens
attributes.brief: The number of tokens used in the GenAI input (prompt).

attributes.name: gen_ai.usage.output_tokens
attributes.brief: The number of tokens used in the GenAI response (completion).

attributes.name: gen_ai.token.type
attributes.brief: The type of token being counted.

attributes.name: gen_ai.prompt
attributes.brief: The full prompt sent to the GenAI model.
attributes.note: It's RECOMMENDED to format prompts as JSON string matching [OpenAI messages format](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-generation)

attributes.name: gen_ai.completion
attributes.brief: The full response received from the GenAI model.
attributes.note: It's RECOMMENDED to format completions as JSON string matching [OpenAI messages format](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-generation)

attributes.name: gen_ai.operation.name
attributes.brief: The name of the operation being performed.
